title: Assistant Professor in Product Design & Manufacture (Part time)
field: Manufacturing Engineering, Materials Engineering, Product Design,
job_description: Reference ENG026322Closing Date Monday, 14th March 2022Job Type TeachingDepartment Mechanical Materials & Manuf EngSalary Â£40927 to Â£50296 per annum pro-rata depending on skills and experience. Salary progression beyond this scale is subject to performance.The University of Nottingham seeks applications for a part-time Assistant Professor in Product Design and Manufacture to contribute to teaching on our growing undergraduate taught programs in this area. This role is offered as teaching and learning only. It is anticipated that this might also appeal to someone moving into academia from industry as well as existing academics with a T&L focus. It is expected that the ideal candidate will have expertise in the area of product design and manufacture, with knowledge of engineering design methods (including familiarity of CAD and visualisation software) and digital manufacturing. Applications are particularly welcome from individuals with teaching or industrial experience within this field.   We particularly welcome applications from staff with protected characteristics, such as BAME, disabled and LGBT+ communities. We also encourage staff who are under-represented in their professional field e.g. for reasons such as gender, to apply.The role holder will contribute to the planning, design, development and delivery of materials for programmes in the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering.  The role will include the development of course curricula and teaching materials as required.This post is offered on a permanent basis. We are offering this part-time position between 0.1 and 0.24FTE (Maximum 8.75 hours).Please direct informal enquiries to Simon Harrison (Programme Director for Product Design and Manufacture) (Simon.Harrison@nottingham.ac.uk). Please note that applications sent directly to this email address will not be accepted.Our University has always been a supportive, inclusive, caring and positive community.
